questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

 

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

 

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints;

B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. In rheumatoid arthritis, upper cervical spine & hip joint are less commonly involved. There is atlantoaxial joint subluxation when cervical spine is involved. Lumbar spine is usually spared. The chronic inflammatory synovitis in the cervical spine results in severity that progresses to bone erosion and ligamentous laxity, leading to late spinal instability. The most common radiological presentations of spinal involvement in RA are: atlantoaxial subluxation, cranial settling (also known as basilar impression, atlantoaxial impaction or superior migration of the odontoid, the most severe form of spinal instability in RA), subaxial subluxation or a combination of them.

 

 

Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. In the involvement of spine & pelvis in psoriatic arthritis, the patient experiences extreme back/neck pain, stiffness in back/neck that improves on moving around. The stiffness worsens by a period of rest. There is difficulty in bending or moving the back. The patient also complaints of fatigue. The x-ray shows asymmetric paravertebral ossification, thicker & larger syndesmophytes than ankylosing spondylitis. Occasionally, there are incomplete non-marginal syndesmophytes similar to AS.

 

 

Option D. Paget’s disease. It is characterized by excessive disorganized bone turnover, that encompasses excessive osteoclastic activity initially followed by disorganized excessive new bone formation. Osteoclast appears larger and irregular whereas osteoblast are relatively normal. Etiology is genetic infection by paramyxovirus (measles and respiratory syncytial virus). There is increased bone resorption accompanied by accelerated bone formation. Most people are asymptomatic. The sites most commonly involved are pelvis, tibia, followed by skull, spine, clavicle and femur. Affects men > 50 years more commonly. Pain is most common presenting symptom. The spine is the second most commonly affected site (53%), after the pelvis (70%). The lumbar spine and more commonly the L4 and L5 levels are the most frequently involved sites. Involvement of the atlanto-axial region is very rare. The vertebral body is almost always involved with a portion of the neural arch. The radiological appearance is characterised by an increase in the antero-posterior and lateral vertebral dimensions. The height of the vertebra is unchanged. The vertebral end-plates are subchondral condensations of trabecular bone and do not represent true bony cortex, i.e. there is no periosteum/endosteum interface at the caudal/cranial aspect of a normal vertebra. The “early” radiographic appearance of vertebral body is thickening and hypertrophy of the trabecular bone, parallel to the end plates. Progression of the sclerotic phase in the spine leads to “ivory vertebra”, due to an increase in the density of the vertebral body.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A patient is being treated with phenobarbitone. Which of the following is inhibited? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Complex I → coenzyme Q


Phenobarbitone is known to affect the electron transport chain, specifically inhibiting the transfer of electrons from Complex I to coenzyme Q. Complex I, also known as NADH dehydrogenase and NADH CoQ oxidoreductase, takes hydrogen from NADH and transfers electrons to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone). This step is crucial in the electron transport chain as it initiates the flow of electrons, which is essential for ATP production. Phenobarbitone inhibits this specific step, disrupting the electron flow, which impairs cellular energy production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Complex II → coenzyme Q: This step involves the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, a different pathway not directly affected by phenobarbitone.

 

Option C. Complex III → Cyt. C: This step transfers electrons from coenzyme Q to cytochrome C, an independent part of the electron transport chain not impacted by phenobarbitone.

 

Option D. Complex IV → oxygen: This final step involves the transfer of electrons to oxygen, forming water. Phenobarbitone does not inhibit this part of the chain.

 

Educational Objective:


Phenobarbitone specifically inhibits the electron transport between Complex I and coenzyme Q, disrupting ATP production.

choices.text: TACE is used for multinodular lesions
Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm
The incidence of HCC is increasing
NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC

questions.text: Identify the false statement out of the following: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lenvatinib is used for lesions less than 3 cm

 

Lenvatinib is used to treat advanced stages of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Treatment of lesions less than 3 cm is wide excision or liver transplant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TACE is used for multinodular lesions: True. TACE (Transarterial chemoembolization) combined with other treatments is used for unresectable multiple nodular and massive HCC, especially when a single nodular diameter is greater than 5 cm (intermediate or advanced HCC).

 

Option C. The incidence of HCC is increasing: True. The incidence of HCC is increasing worldwide due to the increase in HCV and HBV infections, along with lifestyle disorders like obesity.

 

Option D. NASH (Non-Alcoholic Steatohepatitis) and NAFLD (Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease) are risk factors for HCC: True. Obesity is associated with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NALD), which progresses to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) causing cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma. Thus, NASH and NAFLD are risk factors for HCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Barcelona-Clinic-Liver Cancer (BCLC) Classification is the commonly used staging system for HCC.
  • Very early HCC is treated by ablation, early HCC with a single nodule is resected, and when there are multiple nodules over 3 cm, ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate stage HCC is treated by chemoembolization, and TACE (Trans-arterial chemoembolization) is used for multinodular lesions.
  • Advanced stages of the disease with macrovascular invasion are treated with systemic therapies. Lenvatinib and sorafenib are first-line drugs.
  • Supportive care is given at the terminal stage of the disease.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

 

The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i). Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii). Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphemia or pseudo hypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii). Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv). Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes.
  • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:
  • V – Vincristine
  • E – Etoposide
  • C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: A malignant brain tumor located in the posterior fossa, not associated with intraocular findings or leukocoria.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma affecting muscles, often presenting as a mass in the orbit but not causing leukocoria or associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option D. Astrocytoma: A tumor of the central nervous system (glial origin), which does not occur intraocularly and is not linked with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.

 

Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
 

1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE

  • This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.

 

2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.

 

3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infection

 

  • The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme (EMF)
  • Most common cause – Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from Type IV cell-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • It most commonly occurs following an infection with Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

 

 

Location:

 

  • Palms and the trunk.
  • Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions.
  • It presents as the classic acral iris or 'Target lesions'.

 

The common triggers apart from Herpes simplex infection are:

 

  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulphonamides, rifampicin, penicillin derivatives.

 

Note: Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens Johnson syndrome (SJS) & Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drugs: While drugs can trigger EMF, they are not as commonly implicated as infections, especially HSV.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccinations can occasionally trigger EMF but are less commonly a cause compared to infections.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Although malignancies can sometimes trigger EMF, they are much less common triggers compared to infections like HSV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common trigger for erythema multiforme, particularly when target lesions are present on the palms, is infection, notably with herpes simplex virus.

 

Additional information

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7462 Unique Key-Q3225777

questions.text: A 22y type 1 DM is in the post operative ward following a cesarean done for failed induction (for preeclampsia with severe features). She complains of drowsiness and altered sensorium. She is on maintenance MgSO4 infusion and on IV infusion of insulin. On examination, her PR is 70/ min. BP is 140/ 98 mmHg. RR is 10/min. Auscultation of lungs reveals bilateral normal air entry. Abdominal examination reveals a firm uterus with normal tenderness. Pfannenstiel scar is intact and there is no significant vaginal bleeding. B/l patellar reflexes are absent. A urine dipstick for protein and sugar is negative and a capillary glucose sample is 270 mg%. The suspected diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Magnesium sulphate toxicity

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given clinical scenario and examination finding of B/L absent knee reflex and respiratory depression following magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) administration for preeclampsia suggest the cause of her condition to be magnesium sulfate toxicity.
  • MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia.
  • The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L
  • When on MgSO4, patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity:
  • A woman on MgSO4 for management of eclampsia requires the following to be checked for Mg toxicity:
    1. Deep tendon reflexes
    2. Respiratory Rate
    3. Urine Output
  • Magnesium toxicity occurs at these levels
    • At > 7-10 mEq/L: Loss of DTR
    • 10 - 12 mEq/L: Respiratory depression
    • 25 mEq/L: Cardiac arrest
  • Antidote for Mg toxicity: Ca gluconate (1 g IV)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diabetic ketoacidosis: This is unlikely as urine for sugars is absent.

 

Option C. Postpartum eclampsia: This is unlikely as there is no history of seizures

 

Option D. Peripartum cardiomyopathy: There is no evidence of cardiac failure and hence this is also unlikely

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering magnesium sulfate for preeclampsia, it is critical to monitor for signs of magnesium toxicity, which include loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, and cardiac arrest. The antidote for magnesium toxicity is calcium gluconate.

 

Ref: Page no 1860, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and a gradual onset of fever. A lumbar puncture is performed, revealing an elevated opening pressure and a cerebrospinal fluid analysis, showing a positive India Ink stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryptococcus neoformans

 

Explanation:

 

The key points that support the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis are:

The patient is HIV-positive, indicating an immunocompromised state.

The presentation of persistent headache, confusion, and gradual onset of fever is consistent with meningitis.

 

The lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, which is seen in meningitis.

The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis shows a positive India Ink stain, which is a negative stain used to detect capsulated organisms like Cryptococcus neoformans.


Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that commonly causes chronic meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

 

Indian Ink Preparation showing Cryptococcus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis: While the symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are consistent with bacterial meningitis, the positive India Ink stain indicates the presence of a fungal organism rather than bacteria.

 

Option B. Viral encephalitis: The symptoms and elevated CSF pressure are not typically seen in viral encephalitis, which primarily affects the brain parenchyma rather than the meninges. Additionally, the positive India Ink stain is not consistent with a viral etiology.

 

Option D. Tuberculous meningitis: Although tuberculous meningitis is a chronic form of meningitis, it is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, a bacterium, and would not result in a positive India Ink stain, which is specific for detecting Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungus that can cause meningitis in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

 

A positive India Ink stain on CSF analysis, along with elevated opening pressure and compatible clinical symptoms, strongly suggests Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to an antenatal clinic at PHC and gives a history of Diabetes in her mother. Diabetic screening is carried out for this pregnant woman at
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-28 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Diabetic screening in pregnant women, especially those with a family history of diabetes, is typically performed between 24 to 28 weeks of gestation. This period is chosen because it is when insulin resistance usually begins to increase due to hormonal changes in pregnancy. The screening is done using the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) to confirm gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic screening for pregnant women is best performed between 24-28 weeks of gestation using the oral glucose tolerance test to diagnose gestational diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Components of the MELD (2016) score are all except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Albumin

 

The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score is used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation and assesses the severity of chronic liver disease. The MELD score includes three laboratory values:

 

“CBI mnemonic = Creatinine, Bilirubin, INR are the parameters is MELD score.

 

Currently Sodium levels to the score and MELD-Na score used for prognostication. Hyponatremia associated with adverse outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bilirubin: Reflects the liver's ability to excrete bilirubin.

 

Option C. INR (International Normalized Ratio) for prothrombin time: Indicates the liver's ability to synthesize clotting factors.

 

Option D. Creatinine: Assesses renal function, which can be compromised in liver failure. Additionally, sodium was added to the MELD score to improve its prognostic accuracy, resulting in the MELD-Na score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is not a component of the MELD score. The key components are bilirubin, creatinine, and INR, with sodium also included in the updated MELD-Na scoring system to better predict outcomes in patients with end-stage liver disease.

 

Reference: Harrison 21/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

questions.text: Patient with high triglycerides esterified with long chain fatty acid (LCFA) presents with fatigue and biopsy of muscle shows fat vacuoles. Which of the following is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

 

Carnitine deficiency is a condition in which there is insufficient carnitine to transport long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation, which is the process that generates energy from fats. As a result, LCFAs cannot be oxidized and accumulate in tissues, leading to fatigue, muscle weakness, and the presence of fat vacuoles on muscle biopsy. The accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids is characteristic of carnitine deficiency because LCFAs bind to glycerol when they are not oxidized. This condition often presents with symptoms such as exercise intolerance, muscle pain, and, in severe cases, rhabdomyolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. FA synthase defect: Fatty acid synthase (FAS) is an enzyme that helps in the synthesis of fatty acids in the body. A defect in FAS usually does not present with the clinical picture seen here since fatty acids can be provided through the diet. It is often benign and does not lead to the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscles or the described clinical symptoms.

 

Option C. LPL defect: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is an enzyme that breaks down triglycerides in chylomicrons and very low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) into free fatty acids for tissue uptake. An LPL defect leads to type 1 hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated triglycerides, pancreatitis, abdominal pain, and eruptive xanthomas, which do not match the clinical scenario described in the question.

 

Option D. LDL receptor defect: A defect in the LDL receptor results in type 2a hyperlipoproteinemia, characterized by elevated LDL cholesterol levels, tendon xanthomas, and a higher risk of atherosclerosis. This condition does not involve the accumulation of fat vacuoles in muscle or present with fatigue related to long-chain fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine is essential for the transport of long-chain fatty acids into the mitochondria for beta-oxidation. Deficiency in carnitine leads to the accumulation of triglycerides esterified with long-chain fatty acids in muscle tissues, causing fatigue and exercise intolerance

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4

 

The given image shows characteristic features of Hymenolepis nana. This can be identified by its body segments being broader than long.

 

The egg of hymenolepis nana is roughly spherical or ovoid, 30-40 μm size. It has a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophore enclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granules and 4-8 thread like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore with 6 hooklets as seen in the image. The eggs float in saturated solution of salt and are non-bile stained. They are immediately infective and unable to survive for more than 10 days in external environment.

 

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with breathlessness and cough. His recent CD4 count was less than 200 and the patient’s chest X-ray is shown. BAL was done and reports are pending. What is the likely diagnosis and treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocystis jiroveci; Cotrimoxazole

 

The patient, an HIV-positive individual with a CD4 count of less than 200, presents with symptoms of breathlessness and cough. The chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates. These findings are highly suggestive of Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), also known as Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). This condition is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV infection.

 

The standard treatment for PJP is cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mucor; Amphotericin B: Mucormycosis typically presents with necrotizing infection of the sinuses, brain, or lungs, often in diabetic or immunocompromised patients, but it does not typically present with the bilateral infiltrates seen in the X-ray.

 

Option C. Aspergillus; Voriconazole: Aspergillosis often presents with focal infiltrates or cavitations rather than diffuse bilateral infiltrates. It is also less common in patients with HIV compared to PJP.

 

Option D. Candida; Fluconazole: Pulmonary candidiasis is rare and usually occurs in severely immunocompromised patients, often presenting with multiple nodular infiltrates rather than the diffuse pattern seen in PJP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an HIV patient with a CD4 count less than 200, presenting with breathlessness and bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray, the likely diagnosis is Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP), and the treatment of choice is cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option C. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option D. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: A skin rash gets exaggerated on sun exposure is repaired by which mechanism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleotide excision repair

 

 

Exposure to ultraviolet (UV) rays from the sun causes damage to DNA by inducing the formation of thymidine dimers, which are covalent linkages between adjacent thymine bases on a DNA strand. These dimers distort the DNA structure, interfering with replication and transcription.

 

Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the primary mechanism used by cells to repair this type of damage. The NER pathway identifies the bulky lesions caused by thymidine dimers, excises the damaged section of DNA, and fills in the gap with the correct nucleotides using a DNA polymerase.

 

A defect in this repair mechanism can lead to xeroderma pigmentosum, a condition characterized by extreme sensitivity to UV light, leading to severe sunburns, rashes, and a high risk of skin cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Base excision repair: This mechanism repairs small, non-bulky DNA lesions such as single-base alterations, including deamination and oxidative damage. It does not correct UV-induced thymidine dimers.

 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA break repair: This repair mechanism is involved in fixing double-strand breaks, which occur due to radiation, replication errors, or certain chemicals. It does not address thymidine dimers.

 

Option C. Mismatch repair: Mismatch repair corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as incorrect base pairing (e.g., A-C instead of A-T). It is not involved in repairing damage from UV light exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nucleotide excision repair is the primary DNA repair mechanism that corrects damage caused by UV light, such as thymidine dimers.

questions.text: A worker in an industry for the last 20 years develops dry cough and chest tightness. He had the following finding in his pulmonary biopsy. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Asbestosis

 

The biopsy image and clinical history suggest a diagnosis of asbestosis. Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by prolonged inhalation of asbestos fibers, commonly seen in workers exposed to construction, shipyard, or insulation industries.

 

The characteristic finding in the biopsy is the presence of asbestos bodies, which appear as beaded or dumbbell-shaped fibers coated with iron-rich proteinaceous material, giving a beaded appearance.

 

 

This is the key diagnostic feature that differentiates asbestosis from other pneumoconioses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Typically occurs in workers exposed to silica dust, such as those in mining, sandblasting, or construction. It is characterized by nodular fibrosis in the upper lobes and does not show the beaded appearance of asbestos fibers on biopsy.

 

Option B. Anthracosis: Also known as coal worker’s pneumoconiosis, this condition results from the inhalation of coal dust. It presents with black lung tissue and anthracotic pigment but lacks the distinct asbestos bodies seen in asbestosis.

 

Option C. Berylliosis: Caused by inhalation of beryllium particles, typically affecting workers in the aerospace, electronics, or manufacturing industries. It presents with non-caseating granulomas on biopsy, not the beaded asbestos fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asbestosis is characterized by the presence of asbestos bodies with a beaded or dumbbell appearance on lung biopsy, often seen in workers with long-term exposure to asbestos fibers.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: What is the dose of Ulipristal used in emergency contraception? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30 mg

 

Explanation:

 

The dose of Ulipristal in emergency contraception is 30 mg to be taken within 72 hrs (can be taken upto 120hrs).

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dose of Ulipristal for emergency contraception is 30 mg, to be taken within 72 hours (up to 120 hours) after unprotected intercourse.

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: You are a public health officer in a remote village experiencing a rise in dog bites due to an increase in stray dogs. The local panchayat asks you to teach the villagers essential first aid steps after a dog bite. Which method would you primarily use? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Demonstration

 

Performing the method of washing the wound in front of the villagers will be the best way to teach them. This method is called Demonstration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panel discussion: Best for discussing various viewpoints but not ideal for teaching practical skills.

 

Option B. Flash cards: Useful for quick information and reminders but not as effective for demonstrating practical steps.

 

Option D. Symposium: Suitable for delivering in-depth information and discussions but not for practical demonstrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Demonstration is the most effective method for teaching practical first aid steps, such as wound care after a dog bite, especially in settings with limited healthcare access.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

questions.text: Identify the condition according to given image below.(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trophic ulcer

 

  • Image given is of trophic ulcer, typically seen in diabetic patients because of lack of sensation.
  • They are seen on weight bearing parts of foot.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trophic ulcers, commonly seen in diabetic patients, are typically found on weight-bearing parts of the foot and are characterized by their punched-out appearance with hyperkeratotic edges and undermined borders.
  • They are primarily caused by peripheral neuropathy, leading to a lack of sensation in the affected areas. Proper foot care and regular inspection are crucial in preventing these ulcers.

questions.text: Most common hernia in females (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Indirect inguinal hernia

 

The most common type of hernia in females is the inguinal hernia, and specifically, the indirect inguinal hernia. This can be confusing because femoral hernias are indeed more common in females compared to males, but the indirect inguinal hernia remains the most prevalent overall in females.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct inguinal hernia: Incorrect. While inguinal hernias are common, the direct inguinal hernia is less common than the indirect inguinal hernia in both males and females.

 

Option C. Femoral hernia: Incorrect. Femoral hernias are more frequently seen in females compared to males, but they are not the most common type of hernia in females overall.

 

Option D. Obturator hernia: Incorrect. Obturator hernias are rare and not the most common type of hernia in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In females, the most common type of hernia is the indirect inguinal hernia, despite femoral hernias being more common in females compared to males.

 

Incidence of Hernia in Females: Indirect inguinal Hernia > Direct inguinal Hernia > Femoral hernia

questions.text: Match the mode of inheritance with the disorder in the appropriate column: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B

 

1. Autosomal Dominant -  D. Myotonia dystrophica

  • Autosomal dominant disorders are typically inherited from one affected parent. Myotonia dystrophica, characterized by muscle stiffness and other systemic symptoms, exhibits this pattern of inheritance.

 

2. X-Linked Recessive – A. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy

  • X-linked recessive disorders mainly affect males and are passed on by carrier mothers. Duchene Muscular Dystrophy, which leads to muscle degeneration and weakness, is a classic example.

 

3. Autosomal Recessive – C. Cystic fibrosis

  • Autosomal recessive disorders require both parents to pass on a faulty gene. Cystic fibrosis, which causes severe damage to the respiratory and digestive systems, is inherited this way.

 

4. Mitochondrial – B. Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy (Leber's disease)

  • Mitochondrial diseases are inherited through mutations in mitochondrial DNA, typically passed from mother to all offspring. Leber's disease leads to sudden vision loss primarily in young adults.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Each genetic disorder has a specific pattern of inheritance that affects its transmission and manifestation in individuals.

questions.text:
To study the effect of Vitamin C consumption on the occurrence of Respiratory disease, arrange the steps of a case-control study in sequence. [NEET PG 2024]


1 – Measurement of exposure.
2 – Matching.
3 – Analysis and interpretation.
4 – Selection of cases and controls.
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 4-2-1-3

 
A case-control study is a retrospective observational study design commonly used to investigate the causes of a condition or disease. The steps are as follows:

 

4. Selection of cases and controls : The first step involves identifying the cases (individuals with the disease) and controls (individuals without the disease). In this example, cases would be people with respiratory disease, and controls would be those without it.

 

2. Matching : The next step is to match the cases and controls on various confounding factors such as age, gender, or lifestyle to minimize bias.

 

1. Measurement of exposure : After matching, the history of exposure to the risk factor (in this case, Vitamin C consumption) is measured for both cases and controls by collecting historical data.

 

3. Analysis and interpretation : Finally, data is analyzed, often using a 2x2 table to calculate the odds ratio, which determines the association between the exposure and the disease. An odds ratio greater than 1 indicates a positive association, less than 1 indicates a protective effect, and equal to 1 indicates no association.

 

Educational Objective:


The correct sequence of steps in a case-control study is: Selection of cases and controls, matching, measurement of exposure, and then analysis and interpretation.

choices.text: LH from maternal pituitary
HCG from placenta
Inhibin from corpus luteum
GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • HCG from placenta:
    • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
    • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
    • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
    • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
    • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
    • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LH from maternal pituitary: Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.

 

Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum: Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.

 

Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus: GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

 

Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is the site of drainage of the marked structure? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphenoethmoidal recess

 

The identified anatomical feature corresponds to the sphenoid sinus, which effectively empties into the Sphenoethmoidal recess.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior meatus: This meatus drains the posterior ethmoid sinus.

 

Option B. Middle meatus: The middle meatus is the drainage site for several other sinuses, including the frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, and anterior ethmoid sinus. It is the most common drainage site for these sinuses, but not for the sphenoid sinus.

 

Option C. Inferior meatus: This meatus primarily serves as the drainage site for the nasolacrimal duct, which is responsible for draining tears from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity. It does not play a role in draining any of the paranasal sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 209

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: Which of the following helminthic infections that is commonly transmitted by soil, is characterized by the egg in stool as shown in the image below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichuris trichiura

 

The given image shows the egg of Trichuris trichiura (whipworm).

 

The characteristic features of whipworm eggs are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eggs are barrel-shaped in the middle with a projecting mucus plug at each pole containing an unsegmented ovum. The plugs are colorless.
  • ﻿﻿They float in the saturated salt solution.
  • ﻿﻿It has a triple shell, the outermost layer of which is stained brown.

 

They are commonly transmitted by soil. The eggs passed in the stool are unembryonated. Microscopic identification of the eggs in a stool specimen is diagnostic of whipworm infection.

 

In moderate infections of 20 adult worms or less, the worms are confined to the caecum and ascending colon. The symptoms include epigastric and lower abdominal pain, diarrhea (rarely bloody), vomiting, flatulence and distention, weight loss, and increased blood and iron loss.

 

In heavy infections of 200 adult worms or more (trichuriasis dysentery syndrome), the worms are in the distal colon and rectum. The symptoms include bloody diarrhea with profuse mucus, abdominal pain, tenesmus, weight loss leading to cachexia, severe anemia, and rectal prolapse. On examination, clubbing may be present. Blood investigations may show moderate eosinophilia.

 

Chronic infection leads to growth retardation and nutritional deficiencies. Around 0.005 ml of blood is lost per day per worm. In heavy infections, as much as 4 to 5 ml can be lost per day per worm.

 

Treatment is mebendazole or albendazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ancylostoma duodenale: Causes hookworm infection, characterized by eggs that are oval and thin-shelled, different from the barrel-shaped eggs of whipworm.

 

Option C. Necator americanus: Another species of hookworm with similar egg morphology to Ancylostoma duodenale.

 

Option D. Ascaris lumbricoides: Causes ascariasis and is characterized by larger, oval, and thick-shelled eggs, distinct from the eggs of whipworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognizing the distinctive egg morphology of Trichuris trichiura in stool samples is crucial for diagnosing whipworm infection. Proper sanitation and hygiene are key in preventing soil-transmitted helminth infections, and treatment involves specific antihelminthic medications to reduce the worm burden and alleviate symptoms.

choices.text: Functional residual capacity
Inspiratory capacity

questions.text: Which of the following decreases in pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Functional residual capacity

 

Explanation:

 

Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air remaining in the lungs at the end of a normal expiration. During pregnancy, the diaphragm is elevated due to the enlarging uterus, leading to a decrease in FRC by approximately 22%. This is primarily due to reductions in expiratory reserve volume and residual volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate: The respiratory rate typically remains unchanged during pregnancy, staying at about 14-16 breaths per minute.

 

Option B. Vital capacity: Vital capacity, which is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume, remains unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity increases during pregnancy by about 10%. This increase is due to the higher tidal volume and inspiratory reserve volume.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Functional residual capacity decreases during pregnancy due to the elevation of the diaphragm caused by the enlarging uterus.

 

  • Functional residual capacity decreases in pregnancy.

 

 

Ref: Page no 189, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: All of the following muscles are derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch, except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Levator veli palatini

 

Levator veli palatini: The muscle responsible for elevating the soft palate, playing an essential role in swallowing. It prevents food and liquids from entering the nasopharynx during swallowing. This muscle is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch but from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by the pharyngeal plexus, with contributions primarily from the vagus nerve (CN X).

 

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

 

  • Muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, lateral and medial pterygoids)
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor velipalatini and
  • Anterior 2/3 of tongue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pterygoids: It is one of the muscles of mastication which assists in elevating the mandible and plays a role in the side-to-side movement of the jaw. It originates from the medial pterygoid plate of the sphenoid bone and the pyramidal process of the palatine bone and inserts into the medial surface of the mandible. The medial pterygoid is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Lateral pterygoids: Like the medial pterygoid, it is also a muscle of mastication which depresses the mandible and side-to-side jaw movements. The muscle has two heads, superior and inferior, and it inserts into the neck of the mandible and the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint. Derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch, it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option D. Tensor veli palatini: It is responsible for tensing the soft palate and assists in opening the auditory (Eustachian) tube, equalizing the pressure between the middle ear and the nasopharynx. This muscle is derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch and is unique among the palatal muscles because it is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum
Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

questions.text: Which of the subsequent pairs are inaccurately matched? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum

 

Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells (Not M cells) present in the stomach, small intestine, and colon.

M cells, or microfold cells, are specialized epithelial cells in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue (GALT) that play a crucial role in initiating mucosal immune responses, it does not release Motilin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrin - G cells, Antrum: Correct. Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum of the stomach and stimulates H+ secretion by parietal cells.

 

Option B. Secretin - S cells, Duodenum: Correct. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and decreases gastric acid secretion while increasing pancreatic bicarbonate secretion.

 

Option C. CCK - I cells, Duodenum and jejunum: Correct. Cholecystokinin (CCK) is produced by I cells in the duodenum and jejunum, increasing pancreatic enzyme secretion and gallbladder contraction while decreasing gastric emptying and relaxing the sphincter of Oddi.

 

Option D. Motilin - M cells, Duodenum and Jejunum: Incorrect. Motilin is produced by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon, not exclusively by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GIT HORMONES

 

  • Gastrin – G cell at antrum. Acts on Parietal cells stimulate the H+ K+ ATPase.
  • Secretin – S cells at Duodenum. Decrease gastric acid secretion and Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion.
  • CCK-PZ – I cells in duodenum and jejunum. Increase pancreatic HCO3- secretion, Increase gall bladder contraction, Decrease gastric emptying and increase sphincter of Oddi relaxation.
  • GIP – K cells in duodenum and jejunum. Decrease H+ secretion and increase insulin release.
  • Motilin – Mo cells in small intestine. Produces migrating motor complexes (MMCs).

questions.text: Sour taste is mediated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TRPV1 Channel

 

Fig: Signal transduction in taste receptors: Salt and sour tastes are mediated via the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC). This receptor has two subunits (a and g), each crossing the membrane twice, resulting in intracellular N and C termini (NT, CT). Salt is sensed following Na+ movement; sour is mediated by movement of H+. Sweet, bitter, and umami tastes are sensed via G-protein-coupled receptors that span the membrane seven times and have varying lengths of CT and NT (represented as ribbon structures). Sweet tastes are detected by the T1R2 and T1R3 families, bitter and umami tastes are detected by the T2R family and mGluR4, respectively.

 

Fig: Receptors on nociceptive unmyelinated nerve terminals in the skin. Nociceptive stimuli (eg, heat) can activate some receptors directly due to transduction of the stimulus energy by receptors (eg, transient receptor potential (TRP) channel TRPV1) or indirectly by activation of TRP channels on keratinocytes (eg, TRPV3). Nociceptors (eg, mechanoreceptors) can also be activated by the release of intermediate molecules (eg, ATP), ASIC, acid-sensitive ion channel; P2X, ionotropic purinoceptor, P2Y, G-protein-coupled purinergic receptor.

 

Sour taste is primarily mediated by the detection of H+ ions, which are present in acidic substances like citric acid. These H+ ions activate ion channels rather than G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs). Specifically, the TRPV1 (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid Receptor Type 1) channel and acid-sensitive ion channels are involved in mediating the sour taste. These channels open in response to the presence of H+ ions, allowing the ions to enter the taste cells, which leads to the perception of a sour taste.

 

Metabotropic receptors, which involve GPCRs, mediate other taste modalities like sweet, bitter, and umami but are not involved in sour taste. The GPCR T1R1 and T1R3 are specifically involved in the sweet and umami taste pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabotropic Receptor: This type of receptor is associated with GPCRs and mediates taste sensations like sweet, bitter, and umami. It is not involved in sour taste, which is mediated by ion channels.

 

Option C. GPCR T1R1: This receptor is part of the GPCR family and is involved in detecting umami (savory) tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Option D. GPCR T1R3: This receptor is also a part of the GPCR family and contributes to the detection of sweet and umami tastes, not sour tastes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sour taste is mediated by the activation of ion channels, particularly the TRPV1 channel and acid-sensitive ion channels, in response to H+ ions from acidic substances

choices.text: Reduce the swelling and do the observation
Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about a patient who presented in the OPD with a swelling as shown in the image? The swelling is reducible. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Do a surgical procedure and reduce the swelling with mesh repair

 

The image shows a reducible swelling on the patient's back, which strongly suggests a hernia. Hernias are defined as protrusions of an organ or tissue through an abnormal opening. When a hernia is reducible, it means that the protruded organ or tissue can be pushed back into its original place.

 

The standard treatment for a reducible hernia is surgical repair. This often involves reducing the hernia and reinforcing the weakened area with a mesh to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly important to avoid complications such as strangulation or incarceration of the herniated contents, which can become medical emergencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incision and drainage: This procedure is typically used for abscesses or other collections of pus, not for hernias. Hernias do not require drainage as there is no infection involved.

 

Option B. Reduce the swelling and do the observation: While reducing the swelling might temporarily alleviate symptoms, observation alone is not a definitive treatment for a hernia. Without surgical repair, the hernia is likely to recur and may lead to complications.

 

Option D. Observation alone: This option is not advisable for hernias as it does not address the underlying defect in the abdominal wall or the risk of potential complications. Hernias generally require surgical intervention to prevent recurrence and complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For reducible hernias, the appropriate treatment is surgical repair with mesh reinforcement to prevent recurrence and avoid complications. Observation alone is not sufficient, and procedures such as incision and drainage are not applicable.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with growth on talus as seen on foot x-ray. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

  • Osteochondroma is a common benign bone tumor that typically presents as a growth on the bone with a cartilage cap. 
  • In this case, the boy has a growth on the talus, which is characteristic of osteochondroma.
  • X-ray Findings: On x-ray, osteochondroma appears as a bone growth projecting from the surface, often with a cartilaginous cap that is not visible on the x-ray itself since cartilage is radiolucent.
  • Presentation: Patients often notice a palpable mass, which feels larger than what is seen on the x-ray due to the cartilage component (as radiolucent).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma: This is a benign cartilaginous tumor that occurs inside the bone (endosteal). It is more common in small bones of the hands and feet and does not present as an external growth.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma: This is a malignant bone tumor typically found in the metaphyses of long bones, such as around the knee. It presents as a destructive bone lesion with a periosteal reaction, often not seen in the talus.

 

 

Option C. Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone that leads to inflammation. It usually shows a solid periosteal reaction or lytic cavities on x-ray and does not present as a growth. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image shows growth in the talus which is characteristic of osteochondroma of the talus bone. 
  • Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor presenting as a palpable growth with a cartilaginous cap, most often found in young adults, and visible on x-ray as a bony projection.

questions.text: A clinician is attending to several patients with different conditions in a hospital setting. Which of the following diseases necessitates placing the patient in a separate isolation room due to its airborne transmission risk? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Measles

 

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that spreads primarily through the air via respiratory droplets from coughs or sneezes of infected individuals. Its high transmissibility requires that patients be isolated in airborne infection isolation rooms to prevent the spread of the virus to others, particularly the unvaccinated or immunocompromised individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Transmitted through the bite or scratch of an infected animal, rabies does not require airborne isolation as it is not spread through the air.

 

Option C. Nipah: While Nipah virus can be transmitted from person to person, it is primarily spread through direct contact with infected bats, pigs, or other Nipah-infected individuals' body fluids. Airborne transmission is not the primary mode.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis: Generally caused by viral infections and not considered highly contagious through the air. Transmission is typically through direct contact with an infected person's respiratory secretions or feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles necessitates isolation in an airborne infection isolation room due to its high potential for airborne transmission, making it critical to prevent its spread in healthcare settings.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus which lasts minutes to hours with accompanied nausea and vomiting. On investigation, there is endolymphatic hypertension present. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meniere’s disease

The patient's symptoms and the diagnostic finding of endolymphatic hypertension align with Meniere's disease. 

Characterized by episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness, lasting from minutes to hours. The symptoms are due to the accumulation of fluid in the inner ear (endolymphatic hydrops), leading to increased pressure within the endolymphatic system.

Other Options:

 Option B. Otosclerosis: A condition primarily affecting the bones of the middle ear, particularly the stapes. It causes conductive hearing loss, not typically associated with vertigo or tinnitus of the type seen in Meniere’s disease.

Option C. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It involves the dislodgment of otoliths within the inner ear, leading to brief, intense episodes of vertigo, without the auditory symptoms typical of Meniere's disease. 

Option D. Acoustic Neuroma (Vestibular Schwannoma): A benign tumor on the vestibular nerve, leading to progressive, unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disturbances. It usually does not cause episodic vertigo like Meniere's disease.

Educational Objective:

Meniere’s disease is a chronic condition that requires management of symptoms through lifestyle changes, medications to control vertigo, and sometimes more invasive treatments to manage fluid pressure in the inner ear.

questions.text: A patient was started on haloperidol for the treatment of schizophrenia. He develops torticollis, muscle spasm, and trismus. What is the next best step in the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Give benzhexol

 

The patient is experiencing acute dystonia, a common and early side effect of antipsychotic medications such as haloperidol.

 

Acute dystonia is characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, which can manifest as torticollis (neck muscle spasms), muscle spasms, and trismus (jaw muscle spasms).

 

The drug of choice for treating acute dystonia is an anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine or promethazine. These medications help relieve the muscle spasms quickly and are often administered intramuscularly in acute situations.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease the dose of haloperidol: While this might be considered after the acute episode is managed, it does not address the immediate need to relieve the dystonic symptoms.

 

Option B. Shift from haloperidol to clozapine: Clozapine is generally reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia (TRS) and is not the immediate treatment for acute dystonia.

 

Option C. Shift from haloperidol to fluphenazine: Fluphenazine, another typical antipsychotic, can also cause acute dystonia, making this option less effective for immediate relief.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an early side effect of antipsychotic treatment, is managed by administering an intramuscular anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine to quickly relieve muscle spasms.

questions.text: What is the cause of tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Unburnt particles  

 

  • Tattooing is a term used to describe the punctate abrasions observed when skin comes into contact with partially burned or unburned grains of gunpowder.
  • They are also called stippling or peppering. This is seen up to 50 cm of firing
  • They are seen in near (30-50cm) to mid-range of shooting

 

Firearm injuries:

 

 

Blackening – due to deposit of smoke

 

 

 

Grease collar - due to the deposition of the lubricant of the bullet in the tissues

 

Burn injuries - occur due to flame released during the firing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smoke: Causes blackening, not tattooing.

 

Option C. Impact: Refers to the force of the bullet causing tissue damage but does not explain tattooing.

 

Option D. Muzzle impression: Occurs when the muzzle of the firearm makes contact with the skin, leaving an impression, but does not cause tattooing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tattooing around the entry wound of a bullet is caused by unburnt particles of gunpowder embedding into the skin.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reflex, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

The above patient presents with features suggesting an involvement of the trigeminal nerve. The structure marked 3 is the trigeminal nerve

 

The various clinical features associated with trigeminal nerve injury are:

 

  1. Facial pain: Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by severe facial pain, often described as sharp, stabbing, or electric shock-like sensations. The pain is typically triggered by routine activities such as eating, talking, or touching specific areas of the face.
  2. Sensory abnormalities: The trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the face, including touch, temperature, and pain. When affected, sensory abnormalities may manifest as numbness, tingling, or altered sensation in the face. The distribution of these sensory disturbances depends on which branches of the trigeminal nerve are involved.
  3. Facial muscle weakness: The trigeminal nerve also supplies motor fibers to the muscles involved in chewing, such as the muscles of mastication. In certain conditions, such as trigeminal neuropathy or facial nerve palsy involving the trigeminal nerve, weakness or paralysis of these muscles can occur, leading to difficulty in chewing and controlling facial expressions.
  4. Corneal reflex abnormalities: The ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve is responsible for the corneal reflex, which involves blinking in response to corneal stimulation. Disorders affecting the trigeminal nerve may result in a diminished or absent corneal reflex on the affected side.
  5. Headache: Some disorders involving the trigeminal nerve, such as trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (e.g., cluster headaches), can cause severe headaches on one side of the head. These headaches often occur in close proximity to the trigeminal nerve distribution.

 

 

Other marked structures:

 

  • 1- Optic nerve
  • 2- Abducent nerve
  • 4- Vestibulo cochlear nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic Nerve (II): The optic nerve is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain. It is purely sensory in function. It begins at the retina, passes through the optic canal of the sphenoid bone, and joins the optic nerve of the opposite side at the optic chiasm. At this junction, fibers from the nasal half of each retina cross over.  Damage to the optic nerve can result in vision loss. Glaucoma, a condition with increased intraocular pressure, can damage the optic nerve and lead to blindness.

 

Option B. Abducent Nerve (VI): This nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye (moves it laterally). It originates in the pons of the brainstem and travels through the superior orbital fissure to reach the orbit. Damage to this nerve can result in an inability to abduct the affected eye, leading to a condition called lateral rectus palsy. This can manifest as double vision (diplopia) when looking to the side.

 

Option D. Vestibulocochlear Nerve (VIII): It has two parts: the cochlear nerve (for hearing) and the vestibular nerve (for balance). It originates in the inner ear and enters the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle. Damage can lead to issues like sensorineural hearing loss or balance disorders like vertigo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trigeminal Nerve (V) is the largest cranial nerve and has both sensory and motor functions. Sensory functions include facial sensation, and the motor function is mainly for muscles of mastication (chewing). 

 

It has three main branches: ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3).

 

The nerve originates in the pons and exits the brainstem to innervate its various targets. 

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition where there's intense, stabbing pain along the path of the nerve. It's considered one of the most painful conditions in medicine.

questions.text: A patient with HIV who is currently on antiretroviral therapy consisting of zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine is diagnosed with tuberculosis. Considering potential drug interactions, which of the following TB drugs should be changed in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin
